Award.AwardTitle: Manipulation of perovskite dielectrics with high electric fields and large strains
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION:
It is a persistent and important challenge to achieve precise, reproducible, and dynamically adjustable control of materials with applications in electronics, sensing, and clean energy. Electric fields can be useful in this respect because they can produce dramatic and surprising changes in the electronic and structural properties of these materials. New technologies have resulted in the capability to apply large electric fields to very thin layers without destroying them, yielding large but not yet understood effects. This project probes the structural changes induced in thin films of a particular class of materials based on metal complex oxides. Experiments are being conducted using X-ray scattering, precisely characterizing the crystallographic structure in applied fields. Undergraduates and graduate students are involved in experiments at national X-ray scattering facilities and in the interpretation of the experimental results using theoretical calculations. Outreach activities based on the concepts in this project bring concepts related to how the atomic-scale structure of materials is modified by electric fields to wide audiences, including through the creation of on-line structural models.

TECHNICAL DETAILS:
High electric fields promise to provide a new degree of freedom in studying and ultimately controlling and exploiting structural phenomena in perovskite oxide materials. High fields have the potential to induce structural phase transitions, to modify the structural symmetry, and to increase the importance of electrostriction, a largely negligible effect at low electric fields. This project uses newly developed time-resolved X-ray microdiffraction characterization techniques to probe the properties of perovskite complex oxides in high electric fields and at large strains. Experiments are underway to examine the dynamics of recently reported electric-field-driven structural phase transitions between rhombohedral and tetragonal phases, probe the relationship between piezoelectricity and crystallographic symmetry in superlattices, and explore the limits of electrostrictive distortion in complex oxide dielectrics. The project is preparing undergraduates and graduate students for careers in science and technology and exposing them to research at national X-ray scattering facilities. The atomic structure of these complex oxide materials and the structural phenomena studied in this project are presented to broad audiences using a series of interactive on-line structural models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recent advances in chemical synthesis of structurally and compositionally complex metal oxides have yielded a series of materials with promising properties, including ferroelectricity and magnetism.  Oxides with crystal structures similar to the cubic perovskite structure are particularly interesting because they share a common structural motif while simultaneously exhibiting a wide range of physical phenomena.  Controlling and using the functional properties of these materials often depends on manipulating subtle aspects of their crystallographic structure, such as the symmetry of the crystallographic unit cell and the locations of atoms within it. In ferroelectrics, materials with a built-in electric dipole moment, the structure can be modified electrically and can exhibit reproducible transient structural changes in the presence of an electric field.  That is, an external voltage can cause effects that range from a small distortion or expansion of the crystal lattice to a transformation to a completely distinct structural phase. We focus on the structural changes that accompany the application of electric fields with large magnitudes and very short durations.

The intellectual merit of this project arises from discovering and exploiting the links among the structural, electronic, and electromechanical properties of complex metal oxides, and the significant variations in these properties that can result in response to applied electric fields.  Its broader impact includes the professional preparation of undergraduates and graduate students, the dissemination of educational materials, and outreach to the scientific community and the public.

The work supported by this project has resulted in the development and application of novel x-ray characterization methods that capture short-duration transient distortions arising from applied electric fields. This approach involves the use of large-scale synchrotron x-ray light sources and the creation of novel instrumentation to allow these facilities to be used to probe the structure of ferroelectrics at very short timescales. Key aspects of this approach are that it allows structural changes to be captured at the fundamental physical timescales of changes in thin-film device structures, and allows experiments to be conducted that using devices that can be charged and discharged in only a few nanoseconds.  These x-ray methods thus allow the rate of the structural changes including phase transformation to be probed in a way that has not previously been possible. 

A particular area of emphasis is electric-field-induced phase transformations in bismuth ferrite (BiFeO3), a material that exhibits both ferroelectricity and magnetism. Time-resolved x-ray diffraction studies have revealed that large reversible transient distortions can be induced in BiFeO3 by an applied electric field.  When the BiFeO3 thin film is deposited in a way that places it under a low mechanical stress these distortions do not change the symmetry of the film and lead only to a shift of its x-ray reflections due to piezoelectric expansion. At the largest electric fields the piezoelectric expansion is nonlinear, indicating that the system is close to a transition between structural phases. Thin films grown on substrates that induce a compressive strain in the BiFeO3 layer, however, can be driven between distinct rhombohedral-like and tetragonal-like phases by nanosecond-duration electric-field pulses. This project has shown that BiFeO3 layer can be switched between these two phases extremely rapidly, with a characteristic time on the order of tens of nanoseconds. These results provide new tools to enable nanosecond-scale control of the crystallographic phase of materials, and hence functional properties, using applied electric fields.
